                                  • Exercise 3.C

                                  1

                                  Suppose V and W are finite-dimensional and T∈L(V,W). Show that with respect to each choice of bases of V and W, the matrix of T has at least dim range T nonzero entries.

                                  Proof: Let v1,…,vn be a basis for V, and w1,…,wm be a basis for W, the matrix of T is A=(Amn). Then range T is spanned by Tv1,…,Tvn, thus it can be reduce to a basis of range T, which has dim range T vectors, among them, each of these vector is nonzero and is in the form

                                  Tvi=∑j=1mAjiwj

                                  for some i between 1 and n, thus at least one Aji is not zero for one i, we can find at least dim range T nonzero entries in A.

                                  2

                                  Suppose D∈L(P3(R),P2(R)) is the differentiation map defined by Dp=p′. Find a basis of P3(R) and a basis of P2(R) such that the matrix of D with respect to these bases is

                                  (100001000010)

                                  Solution: Let a basis of P3(R) be x3,x2,x,1, a basis of P2(R) be 3x2,2x,1.

                                  3

                                  Suppose V and W are finite-dimensional and T∈L(V,W). Prove that there exist a basis of V and a basis of W such that with respect to these bases, all entries of M(T) are 0 except that the entries in row j, columns j, equal 1 for 1≤j≤dim⁡range T.

                                  Proof: Let dim⁡range T=n, by the fundamental theorem of linear algebra, we have dim⁡V=n+dim⁡null T. let dim⁡null T=k, then we can find a basis of null T to be vn+1,…,vn+k, which can be expand to a basis of V by adding n vectors which we denote v1,…,vn, then Tv1,…,Tvn is a basis for range T, and then can be expand to a basis of W by adding m vectors which we denote w1,…,wm. Consider the matrix

                                  M(T,(v1,…,vk),(Tv1,…,Tvn,w1,…,wm))

                                  If 1≤i≤n, then

                                  Tvi=0Tv1+⋯+0Tvi−1+1Tvi+0Tvi+1+⋯+0w1+⋯+0wm

                                  so the ith column of M(T) has 1 in the ith row. If j>n, then Tvj=0, thus the jth column of M(T) are all zero.

                                  4

                                  Suppose v1,…,vm is a basis of V and W is finite-dimensional. Suppose T∈L(V,W). Prove that there exists a basis w1,…,wn of W such that all the entries in the first column of M(T) are (with respect to the bases v1,…,vm and w1,…,wn are 0 except for possibly a 1 in the first row, first column.

                                  Proof: Consider the vector Tv1∈W, if Tv1=0, then any basis w1,…,wn of W satisfy the requirements. If Tv1≠0, then let w1=Tv1, which can be extended to a basis w1,…,wn of W, we have

                                  Tv1=1w1+0w2+⋯+0wn

                                  5

                                  Suppose w1,…,wn is a basis of W and V is finite-dimensional. Suppose T∈L(V,W). Prove that there exists a basis v1,…,vm of V such that all the entries in the first row of M(T) are (with respect to the bases v1,…,vm and w1,…,wn are 0 except for possibly a 1 in the first row, first column.

                                  Proof: If w1∉range T, then any basis v1,…,vm of V can make the first row of M(T) equal to 0. If w1∈range T, then there exist v1 such that Tv1=w1. Extend v1 to a basis v1,v2′,…,vm′ of V, consider Tvj′ with j≥2, since Tvj′∈W, we have

                                  Tvj′=aj1w1+⋯+ajnwn

                                  for scalars aj1,…,ajn. Let vj=vj′−aj1v1 for j=2,…,m, then

                                  Tvj=Tvj′−aj1Tv1=aj2w2+⋯+ajnwn,j=2,…,n

                                  to finish the proof, we need to show v1,…,vm is a basis for V, and only need to show v1,…,vm is linearly independent. Let c1,…,cm be scalars such that c1v1+⋯+cmvm=0, then

                                  c1v1+c2(v2′−a21v1)+⋯+cm(vm′−am1v1)=0

                                  we get c1−c2a21−⋯−cmam1=0 and c2=⋯=cm=0, this further means c1=0.

                                  6

                                  Suppose V and W are finite-dimensional and T∈L(V,W). Prove that dim⁡range T=1 if and only if there exist a basis of V and a basis of W such that with respect to these bases, all entries of M(T) equal 1.

                                  Proof: Let dim⁡V=m and dim⁡W=n. If all entries of M(T) equal 1 for some basis v1,…,vm of V and w1,…,wn of W, then Tvi=w1+⋯+wn for all vi, so Tvi=Tvj for i,j=1,…,m, thus dim⁡range T=1. Conversely, if dim⁡range T=1, then dim⁡null T=dim⁡V−1, let u1,…,um−1 be a basis of null T, expand it to a basis of V by adding um, then w=Tum≠0, expand w to a basis w,w2,…,wn, then we have w=Tum=1w+0w2+⋯+0wn. Now we define

                                  vi=um−ui for i=1,…,m−1,vm=umw1=w−w2−⋯−wn,

                                  then the list v1,…,vm is linearly independent in V, thus a basis of V, and w1,…,wn is linearly independent in W, thus a basis of W. We have

                                  Tvi=Tum−Tui=Tum=w,i=1,…,m−1Tvm=Tum=w

                                  and w=w1+w2+⋯+wn.

                                  7

                                  Verify 3.36. Suppose S,T∈L(V,W). Then M(S+T)=M(S)+M(T).

                                  Proof: Let dim⁡V=m and dim⁡W=n, choose some basis v1,…,vm of V and w1,…,wn of W, we only have to verify for 1≤k≤m, the kth column of M(S+T) is equal to the kth column of M(S) plus the kth column of M(T). We have scalars ai and bi such that

                                  Svk=a1w1+⋯+anwn,Tvk=b1w1+⋯+bnwn

                                  so the kth column of M(S) is (a1,…,an), the kth column of M(T) is (b1,…,bn). We also have

                                  (S+T)vk=Svk+Tvk=∑i=1naiwi+∑i=1nbiwi=∑i=1n(ai+bi)wi

                                  so the kth column of M(S+T) is (a1+b1,…,an+bn).

                                  8

                                  Verify 3.38. Suppose λ∈F and T∈L(V,W). Then M(λT)=λM(T).

                                  Proof: Let dim⁡V=m and dim⁡W=n, choose some basis v1,…,vm of V and w1,…,wn of W, we only have to verify for 1≤k≤m, the kth column of M(λT) is equal to λ multiple the kth column of M(T). We have scalars bi such that

                                  Tvk=b1w1+⋯+bnwn

                                  so the kth column of M(T) is (b1,…,bn). We also have

                                  (λT)vk=λTvk=λb1w1+⋯+λbnwn

                                  so the kth column of M(λT) is (λb1,…,λbn).

                                  9

                                  Prove 3.52. Suppose A is an m-by-n matrix and c=(c1⋮cn) is an n-by-1 matrix. Then

                                  Ac=c1A⋅,1+⋯+cnA⋅,n.

                                  In other words, Ac is a linear combination of the columns of A, with the scalars that multiply the columns coming from c.

                                  Proof: Let

                                  A=(a11⋯a1n⋮⋮am1⋯amn)

                                  then

                                  Ac=(a11⋯a1n⋮⋮am1⋯amn)(c1⋮cn)=(∑j=1na1jcj⋮∑j=inamjcj)=∑j=1ncj(a1j⋮amj)

                                  it follows that Ac=∑j=1ncjA⋅,j.

                                  10

                                  Suppose A is an m-by-n matrix and C is an n-by-p matrix. Prove that

                                  (AC)j,⋅=Aj,⋅C,1≤j≤m

                                  In other words, show that row j of AC equals (row j of A) times C.

                                  Proof: Let

                                  A=(a11⋯a1n⋮⋮am1⋯amn),Aj,⋅=(aj1⋯ajn)

                                  Then Aj,⋅C is a row, the kth position is ∑i=1najiCik=(AC)jk.

                                  11

                                  Suppose a=(a1⋯an) is a 1-by-n matrix and C is an n-by-p matrix. Prove that

                                  aC=a1C1,⋅+⋯+anCn,⋅

                                  In other words, show that aC is a linear combination of the rows of C, with the scalars that multiply the rows coming from a.

                                  Proof: Let

                                  C=(c11⋯c1p⋮⋮cn1⋯cnp)

                                  Then

                                  ac=(a1⋯an)(c11⋯c1p⋮⋮cn1⋯cnp)=(∑i=1naici1⋯∑i=1naicip)=∑i=1nai(ci1⋯cip)=∑i=1naiCi,⋅

                                  12

                                  Give an example with 2-by-2 matrices to show that matrix multiplication is not commutative. In other words, find 2-by-2 matrices A and C such that AC≠CA.

                                  Solution: Let

                                  A=(1110),C=(0010)

                                  then

                                  AC=(1000),CA=(0011)

                                  13

                                  Prove that the distributive property holds for matrix addition and matrix multiplication.

                                  Proof: Let A=(aij)m×n,B=(bij)n×p and C=(cij)n×p, then AB and AC are m×p matrices, thus AB+AC make sense. For A(B+C), the element in the ith row and jth column is

                                  uij=∑k=1naik(bkj+ckj)=∑k=1naikbkj+∑k=1naikckj

                                  which is exactly the element in the ith row and jth column of AB+AC.

                                  14

                                  Prove that matrix multiplication is associative.

                                  Proof: Let A=(aij)m×n,B=(bij)n×p and C=(cij)p×q, then BC is a n×q matrix, thus A(BC) make sence. The element of A(BC) in the ith row and jth column is

                                  uij=∑k=1naik(∑l=1pbklclj)=∑k=1p(∑l=1nailblk)

                                  which is the element of (AB)C in the ith row and jth column.

                                  15

                                  Suppose A is an n-by-n matrix and 1≤j,k≤n. Show that the entry in row j , column k, of A3 (which is defined to mean AAA) is

                                  ∑p=1n∑r=1nAj,pAp,rAr,k.

                                  Proof: Use matrix multiplication to verify, the details are ommitted.
